Name: BENOMYL
Description: Benomyl is a member of the class of benzimidazoles that is the methyl ester of [1-(butylcarbamoyl)-1H-benzimidazol-2-yl]carbamic acid. A foliar fungicide used to control a wide range of Ascomycetes and Fungi Imperfecti in a wide range of crops. It has a role as an anthelminthic drug, a tubulin modulator, a microtubule-destabilising agent, an acaricide and an antifungal agrochemical. It is a member of benzimidazoles, a carbamate ester, an aromatic amide, a benzimidazole fungicide and a benzimidazolylcarbamate fungicide.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 124 (1995) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 9 was calculated for benomyl(SRC), from a log Kow of 2.12(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Fuchs A, DeVries FW; Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek 44: 293-309 (1978) (2) Fuchs A, DeVries FW; Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek 44: 283-92 (1978) (3) Helweg A; Soil Biol Biochem 4: 377-8 (1972) (4) Siegel MR; Phytopathology 65: 219-20 (1975)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Mixed cultures from soil and water were able to use benomyl as a sole carbon source but the degradation rate was slow(1). A proposed pathway for the bacterial degradation of benomyl proceeds by 2-aminobenzimidazole(1). Strains of Psuedomonas were isolated from soil and water that could grow on a mineral salts medium with benomyl as the sole carbon source(2). In another study, four strains of bacteria and 2 of fungi, which decomposed benomyl to non-fungistatic compounds, were isolated from loamy garden soil(3). Decomposition (16-34%) of 14C ring-labeled benomyl, during 6 and 12 months incubation periods, occurred only in nonsterilized soil. Ring cleavage of the benzimidazole nucleus and metabolism of this moiety to CO2 is apparently related to the presence of microorganisms(4).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 124

mechanism_of_action.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-315
mechanism_of_action.Value: /Methyl-2-benzimidazole carbamate (MBC)/ ... is a potent inhibitor of DNA synthesis in fungi & is probably responsible for the fungitoxic action of the parent compound.

mechanism_of_action.References: WHO; Environ Health Criteria 148: Benomyl p.82 (1993)
mechanism_of_action.Value: Biochemical studies on the mechanism of action of benzimidazole cmpds have shown that their biological effects are caused by interactions with cell microtubules. These cellular structures are present in all eukariotic cells & are involved in several vital functions, such as intracellular transports & cell division. Benzimidazole cmpds have been used as anticancer drugs & antihelminthic drugs in animals & humans because they act as spindle poisons by interfering with the formation &/or functioning of microtubules. However, eukaryotes are known to be unequally sensitive to each benzimidazole cmpd, which explains the use of these cmpds in helminthiases. Selective toxicity of benomyl & carbendazim for fungi has been explained by comparing their binding to fungal & mammalian tubulin. The different sensitivity of several fungi has also been explained by the different affinity of benomyl & carbendazim for fungal tubulin. Benomyl has been found to bind to fungal tubulin but not to porcine brain tubulin, indicating that mammalian tubulin has no, or at least low, affinity for benomyl. This is an agreement with the observation that benomyl at concns that are lethal for sensitive fungi does not interact with in vitro microtubule assembly in these brain extracts. In vitro ID50 values for several mycelial extracts of various fungal species sensitive to benomyl were all below 5 umol/liter. In vitro rat brain tubulin polymerization was inhibited to about 20% at benomyl or carbendazim concns of 25 umol/liter. For comparison, a standard antitubulin drug in humans such as vincristine inhibited 50% tubulin assembly at 0.1 umol/liter in the same experiment. The assembly of sheep & calf brain microtubule was also found to be unaffected by carbendazim concns higher than 100 umol/liter.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Baude FJ et al; J Agric Food Chem 22: 413-8 (1974) (2) Rhodes RC, Long JD; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 12: 385-93 (1974) (3) Weber JB; pp. 15-41 in Mechanisms of Pesticide Movement into Ground Water. Honeycutt RC, Schadebacker DJ. eds. Ann Arbor, MI: Lewis Publ, CRC Press, Inc (1994) (4) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: In a field study on the fate of benomyl applied to bare soil and to turf, benomyl and its degradation products showed little or no downward movement through the soil (Keyport silt loam, Cecil loamy sand, and Leon Immokalee fine sand)(1). Lab and greenhouse experiments showed that benomyl and its two soil metabolites, methyl 2-benzimidazole carbamate (MBC) and 2-aminobenzimidazole (2-AB), were immobile in soils (organic matter ranged from 0.7 to 83.5 percent) and did not leach or move significantly from the site of application(2). The Koc of benomyl measured in soil is 2,000(3). According to a classification scheme(4), this Koc value suggests that benomyl is expected to have slight mobility in soil(SRC).

plant_translocations.content: Root uptake and translocation of benomyl and its breakdown product, MBC (methyl-2-benzimidazole carbamate), were studied in Toronto creeping bentgrass (Agrostis palustris). When benomyl at 100, 500, or 1,000 mg/liter was sprayed on leaves, upward translocation was found but no downward translocation. Using stolons having either a second and separate root system or two root systems, the roots of stolons with a single root system were established five nodes from the first. These roots were either non-treated (control) or treated with 5, 12.5, or 25 mg/liter benomyl for 24, 48, or 96 hr. Bioassay and thin-layer chromatography showed the presence of fungistatic compounds throughout all tissues of stolons with a single root system. This indicated "lateral" movement of the fungistats.
plant_translocations.reference: Meyer, W. A., Nicholson, J. F., & Sinclair, J. B. (1971). Translocation of benomyl in creeping bentgrass. Phytopathology, 61, 1198-1200.

method.Apply Location: Foliar (leaf blade application) and Root (root-uptake studies)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Maintained in the University of Illinois plant pathology greenhouses. All experiments were conducted in a growth chamber at 22°C, 65% relative humidity, with 12 hr of light (2,500 ft-c). Root-uptake studies involved single nodes from stolons of creeping bentgrass planted in moist vermiculite (Terralite brand) for rooting.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: For root-uptake studies, single nodes from stolons were transplanted into cups containing vermiculite with either distilled water (control) or a benomyl suspension at concentrations of 5, 12.5, or 25 mg/liter. For leaf blade application, leaf blades were atomized with distilled water (control) or benomyl suspensions at concentrations of 100, 500, or 1,000 mg/liter, with or without 100 mg/liter of surfactant (E.I. DuPont's Spreader-Sticker). The results show the effects of extracts from different tissues (leaf, crown, and root) of creeping bentgrass treated with different concentrations of benomyl on the growth of Sclerotinia homeocarpa.

plant_translocations.content: The systemic movement of several xenobiotics was compared in soybean and barley. The more symplastic compounds were also compared to the movement of sucrose. The uptake and efflux from potato tuber tissue were studied and related to the in vivo translocation patterns. The patterns of translocation ranged from primarily apoplastic to ambimobile to symplastic. When the percentage of xenobiotic available for translocation was evaluated, there were major differences in patterns of translocation, primarily between plant genera. In barley, fenapanil, fenarimol, and oxamyl exhibited apoplastic transport, while all three were more ambimobile in soybean. Basipetal transport of oxamyl was 4.2% in barley compared to 30.8% in soybean. Basipetal translocation of benomyl remained very low at 3.0% and 4.1% in barley and soybean, respectively, while sucrose was about 60% in both species. Glyphosate and sucrose were translocated in a similar pattern. The transport of 2,4-D was primarily symplastic; however, retention in the tissue appeared to limit the rate of movement compared to sucrose. Uptake and efflux of fenapanil, fenarimol, and 2,4-D illustrated the possible role that cellular binding or partitioning may play in systemic translocation. In conjunction with the uptake and efflux, the octanol-water coefficients, log P, for fenarimol and fenapanil, 0.67 and -0.03, respectively, are correlated with the possible role of cellular binding or partitioning in the systemic movement of xenobiotics.
plant_translocations.reference: Martin, R. A., & Edgington, L. V. (1981). Comparative systemic translocation of several xenobiotics and sucrose. Pesticide Biochemistry and Physiology, 16(2), 87-96.

method.Test Plant: Barley (Hordeum vulgare L. cv. Fergus) and soybean (Glycine max L. cv. Evans)
method.Apply Location: Foliar (abraded band on barley 2nd leaf or soybean unifoliate leaf)
method.Plant Growth Condition: Grown in silica sand, supplied with half-strength Hoagland's solution every 2-3 days. 16h photoperiod with 350 μeinsteins/m2/s from cool white fluorescent + incandescent lights at 22°C day/18°C night, 65-75% RH.
method.Chemical Preparation: See Table 1 for test compounds, specific activities, amounts applied, label position, and sources. Treatment solutions made in 50% ethanol with 0.05% Tween 20.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 20 μL treatment solution applied to 20mm abraded band on barley 2nd leaf at 3-leaf stage or soybean unifoliate leaf.
method.Other Information: Two series - 1) fenapanil, fenarimol, benomyl, oxamyl, glyphosate; 2) oxamyl, glyphosate, 2,4-D, sucrose. 6-8 reps per treatment. Harvests after 3d (series 1) or 6h (series 2). Treated bands washed with acetone or ethanol to measure penetration. Plants sectioned into treated band, above, below, remaining shoots, roots.
